bibl.title: Surgeon General's Office Record Card, May 5, 1906

div1.p: O'Reilly responds to Sterling's request for information about the career and promotion of Walter Reed. There is also concern about the article “The Public's Forgetfulness” which will be forwarded to the President. The record card is dated from May 5, 1906 to August 15, 1906.[Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Surgeon General's Office Record Card, May 5, 1906
div1.p:
Y. May 5, 1906. To the Hon. John
Sterling, M.C., House of Repre-
sentatives, Washington, D.C. Sir:
In reply to your letter of yes-
terday, I have the honor to in-
form you that Major Walter Reed
Surgeon, U.S.A., was sent to Cuba
in 1900, at the head of a com-
mission to study yellow fever,
and he was able to demonstrate
successfully, and to the satis-
faction of the entire scientif-
ic world, the method of convey-
ance of yellow fever, which is
by the bite of a certain varie-
ty of mosquito (stegomya fasci-
ata.) The germ of yellow fever
has never been discovered and
is probably ultra-microscopic.

The attention of Congress was
called by the Hon. the Sec. of
War, Elihu Root, to the achieve-
ment of Major Walter Reed, in
two successive reports, and he
recommended the promotion of
Major Reed to the rank of Colo-
nel in the Medical Dept.. The
following is an extract from
his report of 1902:

“The brilliant character of
this scientific achievement, its
inestimable value to mankind,
the saving of thousands of
lives, and the deliverance of
the Atlantic sea coast from con-

cial recognition from the Govt.
of the U.S.”

Dr. Reed died, however, in this
city, of appendicitis, Nov. 23,
1902, before Congress was able
to act on this recommendation.

It gives me pleasure to send
you under another cover, a re-
print of an article by Dr. Reed,
giving the details of his exper
